full_conversation:
Seeker: So I'm trying to convince my father who's 87 years old that he needs to use a walker or a wheelchair to get around. Because without that, he's always at risk of falling and injuring himself severely. My dad is very stubborn. He doesn't want to be told what to do and he doesn't want to feel like he's dependent. So how to convince him to use a walker or the wheelchair is a situation that I'm currently dealing with, that's giving me a lot of frustration.

Supporter: You need to talk to your father from a place of understanding, and let him know that you understand how hard it is to give up the freedoms he's enjoyed his entire life. However, he also has a very loving family that is very worried about him, and doesn't want to see him fall and get hurt (or worse). Tell him that him using a walker isn't so much about loosing his independence, it's easing the worries of those who care about him.

Seeker: A complex situation that I'm currently dealing with is trying to figure out how to deal with my credit card debt. I have about $9000 in credit card debt and I am not doing a good job with lowering it, but I instead seem to be adding to it. I have a problem with impulsive purchases and always feeling like the need to buy more, which is something that I'm really struggling with and I'm not sure how to address it. I think the biggest issue with that be that I need to really get to the root of what makes me spend and so that I can figure out how to stop because having this credit card debt is embarrassing and um a source of negative emotions.

Supporter: I understand you have no self control and will allow your finances to control you instead of controlling them. You should be embarrassed because it is not spending out of need but out of want. Cut up your cards and pay your bills.

Seeker: I currently have a substance abuse problem and I'm trying to beat it, but it's very hard and I don't have a lot to really make me wanna get clean anymore. My life sucks and I just don't really feel like there's a point to it anymore.

Supporter: I understand that you are trying to overcome a substance abuse problem but you find it very hard and are having trouble finding a reason to persevere.

Seeker: I had a professional, moral problem. I was in upper management and I found out that the company was about to be sold. A lot of people were gonna lose their jobs. But I was told that if I kept my mouth shut and stayed until the sale, I would get an 80% a bonus from my salary. I lived with it for as long as I could. And then I found them starting to really employ, uh, refer to the employees as numbers in departments instead of as individuals. And that went a little too far with me. I knew that they were going to eliminate whole departments of good people and they wanted to blindside them. I couldn't allow that to happen. I decided to risk the 80% bonus and I started teaching people how to do their, uh, resume so that they can apply for another job. I also help people get other jobs in the end. I did stay until the sale. I did get my 80% bonus. They were very upset that I was telling the employees, but I was in such a position that it was a catch 22 for them. If they got rid of me, then everybody was gonna find out anyway. And if they kept me that maybe the, the place would keep running until the cell shortly after the sale, 90% of all the employees were terminated. I retired at 60 a half. So it cost me quite a few years of income. But in the end I'm satisfied with what I did.

Supporter: That's a really tough situation, and not a lot of people would have responded the same way you did. You did the right thing. You helped a lot of people, even though it was stressful for you, since you weren't sure if you'd get fired and/or lose the bonus. You did a good thing.

Seeker: So, for now I'm struggling with whether or not I should go to grad school. I'm not doing so well on the standardized test. Um, like the G A but like, it's something I really wanted to do. So now I'm thinking if it's, it worth the money, um, would I be any good in it? You know, like, are the benefits gonna outweigh the cost to me? Because it's really expensive and it does take a toll on you to go to grad school. So, yeah.

Supporter: I hear that you're saying that you are considering graduate school, but you are struggling with the standardized tests. I would weigh the pros and cons of this situation - will you be able to find a better job because of it? Will that new role bring you joy? Will it bring you financial security? Will you make enough money to pay off the loans?

Seeker: Uh Yes. So, uh I'm dealing with a uh a, a complex issue uh at work. Um Really, it's just how to proceed with the project. Um There's a request to uh build out a product uh that would be used internally in the system. Um The only issue is is that the system's being rewritten at the same time. Um So it's gonna look totally different in uh about uh 18 months. So the, uh the issue is, uh do we wait 18 months and then build out the actual product? Do we spend the next 18 months making that as good as possible or do we spend three or four months coming up with a minimum viable product that we're just gonna have to totally redo once we move into the new system? And if so, um what are the pros and cons of that? What do we build into that? Um How does that impact the final product once you move it into the new system? So it's a lot going on. It, it really just comes down to do, we want to spend a ton of time and money building something that we're only gonna be using for less than a year or, um, do we come up with some other solution that may not work as well? But we can get out quicker, uh, and then shift to building out a good, like the best product we can build once we move into that new system.

Supporter: I would be happy to give you advice with your work project. I would look into how much work it will take to rebuild the product in a couple of months once the new system is built out and the cost. Based on that information it might be best to not build out their product it is going to cost you more of your time and money to do so. If not then go ahead and build them a temporary fix and let them know the details of what is going on and you appreciate their business.

Supporter: Thank you for sharing your story and situation that you're dealing with. I can understand your sense of worry for others. and especially those that appear to be more vulnerable. I commend you on your caring trait. It is hard sometimes in life when you care but also feel helpless to be able to do anything. But don't feel discouraged and continue to be a caring person. the world needs more people like you.We're all on this planet to help one another.

Seeker: My complex situation that I am currently grappling with is addiction. I've been an opiate addict since 1994 and it used to be a lot worse than I am now. Actually, I was on the streets during the nineties. Um, you know, doing heroin daily committing crimes to get money, you know, prostitution, all that stuff in 2000, in 2001, I got on methadone and things cleared up. You know, I stayed on methadone. I got a job, I became somewhat normal person for like almost 10 years and then I had a relapse was starting to do opiates again on top of the methadone. And now years later I still am dealing with that issue. I'm still on methadone, but I'm using fentaNYL on top of it. So it's, um, extremely hard issue to deal with. I've tried several times to break free from this. I've been in several facilities.

Supporter: Hi,
I would suggest working with a dietitian in order to first determine what nutrients that your body might be missing. Then you can figure out a plan of action by taking a combination of vitamins and foods that also provide the vitamins and other nutrients that your body is probably low in. If you maintain the Mediterranean diet, your drug addiction issues might disappear. I would also recommend using chocolate products to help you step down from using drugs. I've heard it shares the same origin as cocaine and thus would be considered a legal "non-drug, drug".

Good luck.

Seeker: The question I'm grappling with is whether I should include my stepfather in my life. And he's been my stepfather for 23 years. Uh, my mother married him two years after my father passed away. And, uh, we've had a cordial relationship, um, mostly respect and I could really see the reason why my mother loved him. Um, I never was as close to him as I was my father. But I mean, I felt like that we were friends anyway. Uh, however, we did kind of go sour when my mother passed away. Uh, I'm not gonna even go into all that. It's a long story. But let's just say I had some, um, some bitterness about things that happened when she passed and she passed away in October of last year. Well, after she passed away, he became sick with COVID and then he had to have surgery and he was in the hospital for about a month and a half total. And I really tried to set aside my feelings and help him out because he really didn't have anybody else in the world. All his other family is gone. And, um, anyway, I felt like I was just gonna go ahead and keep trying to take care of him as much as possible. However, three months after my mother passed away, he called me one day to tell me he just married this woman and it's a woman who is 70 years old and he's 85. So, um, of course, I know exactly why she wanted to marry him more than likely. It's because she wants to get the house and this is a house that my father paid for. But, you know, that's all here. That's neither here or there. But my whole thing is I felt like it was such a disrespect, not only to the fact that my mother just passed away three months before, but he didn't introduce this woman to me or any of my other family and it just felt very disrespectful and like he didn't really care about us at all. So, um, the thing is he is my son's grandfather and he is contacting me like, well, why don't you ever come see me anymore? And I did tell him that I did not, I mean, I told him straightforward exactly my feelings about everything. But I also have this deep feeling that maybe I should forgive him and go see him. That that's what my mother would want me to do. So that's a question that I'm grappling with

Supporter: If he helped raise you and treated you well, you could include him in your son's life, even if you don't need to maintain a greater relationship with him. At 85, there may not be much time for you son to know his (step) grand father.

Seeker: OK. So the scenario I would like to describe it's me working as a white marketing coordinator. In my role as a wide marketing coordinator, I am responsible for ensuring fair and legal practices in the market place. I work closely with vendors, suppliers and various stakeholders to maintain a level playing field and uphold industry standards. Recently, I have discovered evidence that one of our key suppliers has been engaging in unethical practices such as exploiting labor using child workers and disregarding environmental regulations in their manufacturing processes. The evidence I have uncovered implicates the supplier's top management and if exposed, it could lead to severe legal consequences, not only for the company but also for my own organization. On the other hand, turning a blind eye to these unethical practices would betray the very principles of responsibilities and hold D A as a coordinator. In conclusion, navigating this challenge decision as a wide marketing coordinator requires careful consideration of multiple factors, ethical principles and potential outcomes.

Supporter: Wow. You've got a weighty decision to make. Actually, have you let your company's CEO know? Considering the gravity of your discovery, it might be best if you scheduled a quick meeting with him/her and let the CEO make the decision. That's what they're paid to do, after all -- make decisions. Also, you'd be off the hook. Anyway, just a suggestion.

And, uh, what, how do you respond to that? I don't know. I, I don't know how to respond to it. Um, I just try to be up every day but I'm not up and, uh, it's just very difficult.

Supporter: I can relate to this so much.  I lived with my mom when she got her cancer diagnosis.  She had melanoma that didn't respond to treatment.  I had to learn to take the good with the bad and try to be as supportive as I could as you went through her ups and downs.  Inside I was an emotional wreck, but I didn't want her to see it. Everything your are feeling is valid.  I think you just have to do the best you can.  Try to take it one day at a time.  Also, get support  where you can even if it's just someone to listen.

Seeker: Yes, I have a 32 year old son that, uh, suffers from depression sometime he is, um, he gets to a saddle. Um, he used to talk to me about everything. Uh, he can, um, lately he has been in a really toxic relationship with this young lady that he has a child with. And, um, my baby boy recently told me that he got him and a young lady got into a physical fight and I'm concerned about him because they say his face is swollen and, and, you know, stuff like that. So I'm very concerned about this situation and, um, I don't know if I should call him and just bring up a, you know, another situation so he can talk to me or I should just leave it alone.

Supporter: I absolutely understand how our children will always be our babies, no matter their age, and we feel the need to protect them. As much as we feel that way, our job as parents is to teach them how to be able to stand on their own two feet, because we are not always going to be there to protect them from everything life throws at them. I know you are afraid for your son and grandson. I know that in your son's situation it's hard to see right from wrong. You should be there for him to overcome this issue, and help him get back on his feet. It sure sounds like your son also sees you as his friend, and not juts his dad.

Seeker: The current situation that I'm dealing with right now is financial. It's trying to explain to my husband, uh that we have more bills coming in and not enough money to cover them each month. We end up being short. He gets, uh what do you say? Excited over it? And I try to explain, we don't have enough income to cover the bills and he just don't seem to get it. 31.

Supporter: I think it is important for you to sit down with your husband and really get your message to him. He needs to understand your feelings, as well as give him the opportunity to explain why he feels the way he does about this issue. If this doesn't work, it may be important to seek help from a professional to explain your ideas more clearly and ensure that you both are on the same page. I'm really sorry this happened to you, and I wish your husband was more understanding of your situation. I know it is difficult, and you need to take your time to process this issue. Perhaps returning to this topic a little later on would be best, and that may give him an opportunity to think about it as well.

Seeker: Um Right now I'm dealing with my ex-wife going through tax troubles and to help her navigate those. I have to resubmit several years' worth of tax returns and it's difficult because um it's probably going to affect me. Um A lot of those tax returns were not filed correctly. Uh These are from years we were married and um it's probably gonna end up costing me a lot of money and definitely a lot of time, but I want to alleviate her stress as much as possible. Um just in the interest of our Children and maintaining peace and that sort of thing. So, um as many details as possible, I have to go through like creates and creative of documents to basically make that happen. And um it's going to be a long process and I have like so much to do with work, so much to do with a writing fellowship that I'm joining. And uh there's just a lot to do so. And plus I'm raising our kids, she's not a very attentive mother. So like I have to do a lot of the work there. And um yeah, so, I mean, it's just, it's the time, it's the stress, it's the money. So that's, that's kind of where we're at on that.

Supporter: It sounds like a difficult time right now. I'm sorry to hear you going through that. I don't mean to be too "look on the bright side," but at least this sounds like something that will be done once it's done. There's an end in sight to the joint tax mess and going forward you'll be able to just focus on your own taxes. It sounds like your heart is in the right place thinking about your kids and keeping them a priority in mind. Keep being a good dad and cultivating good times and good memories with your kids. You can do this. You've got this.

Seeker: So the complex situation that I'm dealing with is in regard to my 16 year old son. So he is autistic and he has a history of some pretty severe health issues. He had leukemia when he was 5.5. And because of the treatment, he actually now has a tracheostomy, we are trying to decide what the right course of action is with him. We have tried to remove the trache on several different occasions, the last time being about a year ago and it didn't work. So now we are in a situation where we are trying to decide, do we proceed with this or do we just leave the trache in place? And he has a bunch of different studies coming up and he is going to have to have more surgery, which obviously is never a good thing. So that is what I'm dealing with right now, trying to decide what the best course of action is and how to proceed for him.

Supporter: That sounds like a difficult and stressful dilemma. I am not educated on traches or the pros and cons of removing them, so I can't offer informed feedback, but I hope you're able to make a choice that benefits your son, and that his upcoming surgery goes smoothly.

Seeker: The house that I currently live in has some major structural problems. I have the opportunity to move into a much nicer house. The pros for me moving into the the other house is that it would allow me to take care of another person that needs taken care of and it would lower my current expenses to live there. The problem is that I have a disability that affects my mobility. And if I move to this other house, I will have to go up some very steep stairs to get to my room and that will be very difficult for me. I also need to do major renovations on several rooms in that house before it'll be liable for me. And that will cost me thousands and thousands of dollars. And I'm living on a limited budget right now. If I go ahead and do this and use all that money to make the repairs to the other house, I could be very happy living there. But if something happens to the person who actually owns the house, I could be forced to leave and then lose everything. There's a possibility though that if anything happens to the owner of that house, I may be able to take over the mortgage, but the amount that the mortgage costs is extremely expensive, I could probably afford it, but I'm not positive. So I'm not sure if it would be better for me to stay where I am and try and make repairs to this house, even though I could also possibly lose this house if anything happens to the other person or if I should go ahead and make repairs to the other house and possibly lose everything.

Supporter: After hearing about your housing options it actually seems like you're in a better place, either way, than not. Both options, whether to stay in your current situation or to move have some road bumps, but nothing too extravagant. Yes, both you may have to put money up front, but the outcome of either sound like they would be financially worthy in the end. However if you are asking my opinion, I would say the second option of moving would benefit both you and the person you could potentially help out.

Seeker: A complex situation that I'm in right now, um, is figuring out how to fix my financial situation and overall it's my fault. Um, because I'm the one that spent the money and it's not like I didn't have the money of savings. Um, but it was money that was supposed to go towards my house. And I just thought that because I was depressed at work because I want to want to be moved to a new area. And I, I had been told for the last six months that I was going to be moved and I, I, they just kept putting it off and making excuses. So it just sent me into a really big depression and I thought spending money on a new bed. Sure, not a problem itself because they spent the money for that, which was a few 1000 then that didn't end up working out. So I had to get a new bed to replace the new bed because I originally got the purple mattress that I didn't like it. I felt like it was comfortable and my husband didn't like it. So we got another mattress and then I had to get a mattress topper. So that's currently the situation that has to do with that on how to fix all that because I, uh, you know, it's kind of complex because I can't add any more hours to the day. Um, and, and I work, I mean, I do jobs on here and then I have a full time job, so I'm doing both, but just to get that money back is the complexity of it. Like, like how do I do that without, you know, it's just gonna take, it's gonna take months, I think so. I mean, you know, look, you know, all I can do, I guess is work on it and such frustration that I, I am I did to myself. So, and that's the complexity of it that I don't know how to make more money to fix the situation. Um, I'm carrying a n besides what I'm trying right now.

Supporter: I know being depressed can lead to financial troubles and financial trouble can lead to us being more depressed. Do what you can to get out of the debt you're currently in. That's all you can do. Try not to stress about it too much and save money as much as you can. Know that you aren't alone and that your husband can help out with the financial burden as well.

Seeker: The situation that I'm grappling with is divesting the estate of one of my parents, some of my siblings are not helping out cleaning the house and I don't know whether to include them in the profits from a yard sale that we're going to have. I feel like they do deserve something but they're not helping out in any way. So I'm not sure where to go with that.

Supporter: I think there are different levels of grief and process.  Find something else they might be more comfortable doing

Seeker: I'm currently dealing with a complex situation at my job regarding different software services that would best fit my team going forward. We're up for renewal on a current contract for a current service that has some very clear identifiable gaps that we're looking to solve for. However, the new service that we have does not immediately fill all of the needs that the current system works. So, um trying to balance how to either use both to get approvals for both that to select one versus the other, what sacrifices do we need and what risk to the businesses that put?

Supporter: Understand there are gaps with the current software, but how long will the new software take to get use to and also fill those gaps? Sometimes sales reps will always push the boundary of what possible to get you to sign a contract. 

Is there a way where you can negotiate for the contract with the original software supplier and ask them to see if they can help fill in some of those gaps? Ideally a slow transition from old to new would be better, but that might put the business as risk.

Seeker: I'm 51 years old and I am not close to my father. I grew up in a divorced family and my dad had custody of me. But growing up in the eighties, being a father in the eighties is a lot different than being a father in the nineties. And I was the first child. So my dad had to work two jobs and I never really got to spend much time with my dad. I spend a lot of time with my grandparents and I think of my grandfather as a dad and I regret in life later in life now that I am not close to my dad the way my, I am close to my son. When I had my son, I wanted to be a better father than what I had in the sense of being around, being there for him. As opposed to when I grew up, my dad was never around. But I also understand that he was never around because he had to work and he was providing an income and putting food on the table. So on one hand, I understand why I'm not close to him, but I also regret not being close to him.

Supporter: You were a child and a relationship requires the effort of two people. There are things your father could've done to make you feel more loved. Even though he was working, he could've at least taken a day off and I'm sure he had holidays off. It's very good that you've made an effort with your child and I'm happy you were able to learn from your experience and use it to positively change your future. I hope one day you'll talk to your dad about how you felt and maybe be able to grow closer, it's never too late. Of course only if that's what you want to do.

Seeker: Ok. So I'm dealing with grappling with home ownership and if it's really worth the money, um, I know that technically index funds perform better. I don't know if it's better to put money into a house and all the maintenance with it or if it's better to rent and if I'm gonna purchase a house, where am I gonna live? Um, currently I, I rent a house and that's ok, but it doesn't feel like it's a long term solution and I'm just kind of struggling with what to do.

Supporter: I totally understand what you're struggling with. It's hard to know what to do in this situation, and there aren't many trustworthy, reliable resources out there to help. Homeownership certainly has pros and cons, so you should do what's best for you.

Seeker: My car broke down about two weeks ago and I don't have the money to fix it. So I asked my sister about a week ago if I could borrow the money to fix the car. I have no way to go anywhere and I'm frustrated because my sister has plenty of money and it wouldn't be no skin off her back to loan it to me or give it to me as far as that. But, uh, so far she hadn't because she's a control freak and she likes to control people with her money. It gets frustrating. I've never asked her for no money before, but I broke down and asked her because my car is broke down and I have no other way to get it fixed besides asking her for the money. It's frustrating. I don't know what else to today. So that's about, that's my story.

Supporter: I'm really sorry to hear abut your car breaking down. That's a rough spot to be in, and I have definitely been there  – it's especially frustrating when you have family who do have the money to help out, but they won't do it, for whatever their own reason is. I really hope you can get the money to get your car fixed soon, either from your sister or from someone else!

Seeker: My husband and I are trying to decide whether or not we should buy a house when our current lease ends. So we're worried if we don't do it now that we're kind of, you know, running out of time um to buy a house. Also, we're obviously just throwing away money on a rental that we've been in for a couple of years. So that doesn't make much financial sense either. Uh We also know that interest rates will probably be lower, you know, here in the next year or two, hopefully they'll be lower at least. But it, so in that case, we'll be able to buy a better house or a bigger house. But we're also scared that there might be a bidding war because more people that have also been waiting like us will now want to buy a house. So the situation is just really confusing and it doesn't seem like there's a right answer, um, at this time. So that's frustrating. Obviously, hopefully we come up with an answer soon.

Supporter: That makes a lot of sense. I am sorry you are having such a difficult time deciding what to do.

Seeker: My situation evolves uncertainty with my career. I'm trying to decide if I need to change positions, change jobs that way I can get more experience in the degree um that I currently have. This is a big decision. So something that I'm currently thinking over and trying to analyze whether it's feasible, whether it's the best decision.

Supporter: Career changes can be difficult and even just changing jobs within the same job industry can be tough. If you feel you need to move on to something else then it is probably for the best.

Seeker: The complex situation that I'm currently dealing with is the fact that I need a new roof. This one started to leak after a recent storm and it's very noticeable in the kitchen. Currently, the chaotic weather here is a big factor that's causing a sense of urgency with me. I've gotten bids from multiple companies. However, I'm unsure which one I will eventually have to go with. There are a lot of very complicated factors that go into each bid. Some include some features of the roof. Some don't, some are an additional expense that could be unknown until the roof is nearly completed. Each company also has different warranties, different requirements for the warranties. It's just a complicated mess. It's making me feel very unsure about the future, my future, my house's future and the reasons I bought the house to begin with. I'm a little bit frightened too because it reminds me of the house I grew up in which also had a leaky roof in the kitchen. Unfortunately, given the age of the roof, I'm stuck with a lot of unanswered questions for each bid and I just don't really know who to who to go with.

Supporter: The person is confused and overwhelmed with many choices available for her new roof she wants to get.

Seeker: Hello. So, the complex situation that I'm dealing with right now is looking for a job, uh, post graduation. So I started applying, um, started applying to different jobs my second semester of senior year, um, at the beginning of it, I thought there would be enough time. It definitely hasn't. Um, and also makes me feel very disappointed because I'm like, you know, why, why did I spend, spend $30,000 getting a degree if I can't even get a job with it? And the whole reason why I got the degree was so that I could get a job. Um, yeah, I've been using different kinds of jobs, job boards. Indeed. Linkedin zip recruiter, literally anything I can get my hands on. Um, and out of the fifth jobs that I've applied to, I've maybe gotten four interviews and I've been rejected from all of them. And again, it's disappointing because I also do have a lot of experience in the field that I'm trying to go in. So it makes me think there's a lot of competition or, it just makes me think that I'm not competent.

Seeker: So the, the situation I've been dealing with recently is I am a board member of a nonprofit. And the executive director that we've had for 15 years is, has been absolutely stellar. No, nobody's perfect, but he has built the institution. He's built our reputation. He's hired wonderful staff and yeah, yeah, just the last year or two as he's been approaching retirement, two things have happened. One is, he's started too many new ventures, assuring us. He can handle it where it's, it's clear he's overextended, won't admit he's tired and he allowed the institution to get ho top heavy with administration. Uh So only a slight downturn in, in, in income was a problem because we are contractually committed to more people than we need to get the job done. So our decision was the, since his retirement, it is approaching that he's become very, very destructive to his successor. Uh Would we ask him to leave a couple of months early? And my, yeah, my, my decision in quandary was uh where it do, do I vote to ask him to leave early or let him play out his contract and retire on schedule?

Supporter: I understand your concern for the non-profit and the executive director. You should do what you feel is best for the nonprofit while allowing the director to maintain his dignity.

Seeker: The complex situation that I am grappling with is that my spouse has a chronic illness which involves her being immunocompromised. Therefore, it greatly limits her exposure to the outside world. And by definition, my exposure to it as well. What I am trying to understand is to what extent can I do normal everyday things, not risky things. I'm not looking to go to busy street festivals or anything, but just to go to museums, to visit friends indoors at their houses, to go to a gymnasium, to work out. To what extent can I do that without endangering my partner? My partner is taking a very rigid approach to this, but this is uh this is a struggle for me trying to figure out how to handle this.

Supporter: I completely understand where you're coming from. I have gone through similar experiences in my life, and I can see both sides of the situation. Yes, it concerns your partner's health, but you also have to prioritize your own happiness and freedom. I believe there are steps you can take to minimize risk. Ensure that no members of a household you visit are sick, attend gym and other outings on slow days where capacity at those places are low. Things like that. Make it known to your partner that you find joy in these things, and in having your own sense of freedom. If they still don't understand, then it's something that needs to be addressed.

Seeker: The situations I'm dealing with involves a new associate who works hard. One of the hardest working associates I have when he comes to work, he comes in late, he calls out sometimes he leaves early association trying to find the best punishment to hopefully get him motivated to come in and work hard.

Supporter: Managing employees can be tough, and I am sorry that you are dealing with this situation. Just because your best employee is good at their job does not make them reliable, and that is frustrating.

Seeker: Uh, something that I'm dealing with is actually work related. I feel like my supervisor has some sort of vendetta against me. Um, I have a few times been ignored when asking questions related to doing my job properly. Um, I have been looked over and I'm not really sure where it's coming from. You know, I pretty much in any of the chit chat or anything that goes on there. So I'm kind of confused on what I should do about it. Like, should I take it up with a higher up? Should I just let it slide? Hm. I don't know. So that's something I'm battling with.

Supporter: I understand where your coming from, I think you should ask your supervisor why he or she is ignoring you and if they refuse to answer then go to a higher up and file a complaint about said supervisor.

Seeker: Right now, I'm grappling with a complex situation regarding my job. I've been working at the same job for about five plus years now and while it does pay good and I'm good at doing the job, I've been, uh, pretty jaded over the past few months about, uh, really my lack of advancement at the company, uh, which is probably going to exist for, uh, quite a while now. Um, I really just want to explore, uh, something new, a different career path and it's something that's, uh, pretty difficult and pretty scary to quit. One job that gives me a, a stable, uh, say stable wage and transitioning to another job. It may take a while to even, uh, get another job in the current job market. Um, so that's definitely a situation that's, uh, pretty complex. A lot of moving parts and something that I've been, uh, grappling with for some time now.

Supporter: That is a tough situation.  That must be a hard thing to wrestle with all the time. I think there are definitely ways to make your dream come true, but in a safe way.  You could create a plan for yourself with action steps to help get it out of your head and on paper.  Then you could look at each step that you would need to take and see how feasible it would be.  Talking to a trusted friend or someone that is already working in the field would help as well.

Seeker: My sister died, um, really too soon. And it's was traumatic on everybody and especially her sons and the one son, as much as we try to help him just kind of went crazy and gotten a lot of trouble legally. And he ended up getting arrested and he finally ended up pleading guilty and he's got mental health issues. So they're letting him live at home under like house arrest for his entire sentence. And then he has a more intensive, uh, time seeing like a parole type officer and he's getting a lot of mental health treatment and so forth. But he had to move in with his father who was my sister's ex-husband who does not get along with any of the family. So now my nephew is there, he's not responding to phone calls. I believe his father is in charge of his phone and has the numbers all blocked and we have no way to communicate. We know if we send letters and so forth, they don't reach him and being his sentence is for, um, almost three years, we don't know what to do. My mother's getting older and I'm concerned that she's not ever gonna get to see her grandson again or talk to him and he's, um, just not mentally healthy right now and my mom's older and she just cries and cries.

Supporter: That's a really tough situation. It's hard not to be able so see someone that you love, and not know whether they're safe or not. Hopefully in the near future you will be able to contact your nephew and get in touch with him.

Seeker: Right now, I'm really struggling to try to figure out how to find the time to go back to school. I'm juggling a couple part time jobs and I'm not really making it financially. I do have a family too and I'm going to be taking programming classes. It's kind of like a coding boot camp and I'm hoping that that will help me build some skills to land a better job. But I'm very nervous about being able to pull it off. So I feel like just working, you know, a couple of part time jobs that are pretty flexible. I'm already having a really difficult time, you know, just taking care of stuff, taking care of my family and doing what I have to do right now. I'm really worried about being able to find the time to actually pull off this, you know, this training school program that I want. You know, I feel like I might fail because I'm not gonna be able to devote enough time to it. And it's very nerve wracking because it's super important that I accomplish this

Supporter: It makes sense that you're feeling overwhelmed by all of this. You are juggling a lot at the moment and that is not easy to do. It sounds as though you have a great plan in place to take some programming classes to help your financial situation long term. It can be scary to take that first step into the unknown but so often it pays off. Good luck with it all.

Seeker: My dad is getting older and he lives many states away and I can't afford to go visit him. But I'm afraid that he's gonna pass before I get a chance to go and see him again. So I'm wondering if there's some way I can try to save up money to go and visit or whatever. But at the same time, things are really hard right now financially, um, where we live is pretty high cost of living and, you know, we've had some hard times because of the pandemic. So, you know, I know it's like money is and everything and, um, you can't take it with you when you go and I know that if he passes, I'll regret it for not going to visit him. But I just don't know how I can manage it.

Supporter: That is unfortunate and I can definitely understand the situation. It's sad when distance separates people because as you said it can be very difficult logistically or financially to go see them. My best advice would be to make sure that you still do spend plenty of time with them remotely on phone calls and the like and try to save money in a special fund to go see him.
